div.head: TO THE DESERVING READER.
div.p:
DEserving Reader; every Author, as this scribbling age goes, may finde a Reader well worthy his Labour; but very few Authors publish such Workes as deserve the labour of a discerning Reader. Like to some of our PorcupineTheatrall Pantomimes, who dare adventure in their spongie Labours, begot of a barmie spirit, and other no •… ious vapours, to display a Gentlewoman in her compleatest Nature; though they erre egregiously in her
favour, figure and feature. Peruse this, and returne me answer, if it be not worth thy Labour to bestow an houre or two in the Reading of this Author. Forraigne he is, and yet familiar; choice and dainty his conceits, yet allayed with so sweet a temper, as they retaine in them the relish of a good nature. So free his invention, and so cleare from invection, as it admits no sinister inver
•… nor intention. Whatsoever hee 〈◊〉 inserts, holds apt proportion and connexion with 〈◊〉
Subiect whereo •… hee treates. So as, being not onely a Stranger, but so discerning an Author, hee can expect no lesse than a Candid censure from so deserving a Reader.
